PEER.deftext:
to look carefully, stare

To PEER at something is to look at it long and carefully in order to see it clearly.

“He PEERED through his glasses at the dim object.”

“The children PEERED out at us from behind the fence.”

“Jim PEERED at the street sign in the snowstorm.

” Usage: PEER is usually used with at.

SIGNIFY.deftext:
to mean, show, be a sign of

You can see the word sign in SIGNIFY (although the words are pronounced differently). To SIGNIFY something is to be a sign of it, to show it. See -fy under Suffixes.

“The ship’s anchor on Rhode Island’s flag SIGNIFIES the importance of the sea in the state’s history.

“He SIGNIFIED that he was still there by raising his hand.

” Often the sense of SIGNIFY is to mean. “The seal at the bottom of the page SIGNIFIES that this is an official document.”

TASK.deftext:
a job, duty, chore, assignment A TASK is a job or duty, usually one that is difficult. It is often work that is assigned or given to someone.

“She took on the hard TASK of cleaning the garage.”

“Bob was given the TASK of washing the attic windows.”

“Your TASK for today is to finish Chapter Three and write a summary of it.”

“We divided the TASKS according to age.”

AVALANCHE.deftext:
a snow or rock slide/n An AVALANCHE is a huge mass of snow, earth, or rock which comes crashing down the side of a mountain.

“The Alpine village was completely covered by the AVALANCHE."

“They say any loud noise, like a gunshot, can cause an AVALANCHE."

From this basic meaning, AVALANCHE has come to be used about any sudden great rush or outpouring.

“The young actor received an AVALANCHE of mail after his first movie.”

THRESHOLD.deftext:
thresh’-Old) n.: an entrance, doorstep

A THRESHOLD is a board or stone at the bottom of a doorway or entrance into a building or room. THRESHOLD is usually used simply to mean an -entrance to a room.

“He stood on the THRESHOLD waiting to be admitted.”

“The bridegroom is supposed to carry the bride across the THRESHOLD of their new home.”

Because you cross the THRESHOLD in order to enter, the word has also come to be used about the entrance to or beginning of almost anything.

“He is at the THRESHOLD of a great career in politics.” “This is the THRESHOLD of a new Golden Age in human affairs.”

TRANSFORM.deftext:
to change /nYou can see the word form in TRANSFORM. To TRANSFORM something is to change its shape or form. See trans- under Prefixes.

“Solar cells TRANSFORM sunlight into electricity.”

“Her appearance was totally TRANSFORMED when she changed from blue jeans to an evening gown.”

“The ugly duckling was TRANSFORMED into a beautiful swan.”

When something is TRANSFORMED it undergoes a TRANSFORMATION.

“His TRANSFORMATION from bus driver to movie star happened in less than six months."

In the Pretest, move is the most commonly chosen wrong answer for TRANSFORM, perhaps because TRANSFORM sounds like transfer, which means to move. Other forms of the word: TRANSFORMATION, n.

REPLY.deftext:
an answer, response

A REPLY is an answer.

“His REPLY to the question was hard to understand."

“What did you say in REPLY to that?”

You don’t have to REPLY in words.

“Their REPLY to our request was to laugh at us.”

REPLY is also a verb.

“I REPLIED that I didn’t know anything about it.”

“Please REPLY to his letter as soon as you can.”

TUTOR.deftext:
tyU’-tÔøΩr) v.: to teach, train

TUTOR means to teach or train, usually where one teacher teaches one pupil. To TUTOR someone is to give him private, personal lessons, usually in one subject.

“My father is getting someone to TUTOR me in math.”

TUTOR is also a noun meaning a teacher- or trainer.

“Mr. Jones is looking for a job as a TUTOR of English.”

“Jane never went to school; she was taught at home by a TUTOR.”

PULVERIZE.deftext:
to crush, grind into dust

PULVERIZE comes from the Latin word for dust. To PULVERIZE something is to crush it so completely that it is turned into powder or dust.

“The miller PULVERIZED the wheat between the grindstones.”

In general use the word means to destroy completely.

“The invading army was PULVERIZED by our superior forces.”

“The boxer PULVERIZED his weaker opponent.”

ACCURATE.deftext:
correct, exact

The cur part of ACCURATE comes from a Latin word for care. Something that is ACCURATE is correct, without errors, especially as a result of taking care.

“Her income tax report is ACCURATE to the penny.”

“He made an ACCURATE guess about how fast they were traveling.”

Someone who is ACCURATE does not make mistakes.

“He is usually ACCURATE in his predictions about who will win the election.”

The noun form is ACCURACY. “His ACCURACY in hitting the bullseye on the dartboard was unbelievable.”

“We look for ACCURACY rather than speed in this kind of work.”

Other forms of the word: ACCURACY, n.

ASSIST.deftext:
to help, aid

ASSIST comes from Latin words meaning to stand by. To ASSIST someone is to help him by giving him support or doing something for him.

“Several nurses ASSISTED the doctor during the operation.”

“I wanted to ASSIST my brother, but he said he could do it by himself.”

“His deputy ASSISTED him in writing the report.”

ASSISTANCE is the act of helping.

“The baby didn’t need anyone’s ASSISTANCE in walking across the room.”

Other forms of the word: ASSISTANCE, n. ASSISTANT, n.

CONCLUDE.deftext:
to end; to decide

The verb CONCLUDE has two meanings. The first is to end.

“He CONCLUDED the meeting by asking everyone to leave.”

“The teacher always CONCLUDES the class by asking if there are any further questions.”

CONCLUDE also means “to reach a final judgment,” to decide.

“After a great deal of thought, we CONCLUDED that it was best for her to go to a private school.”

“The detective CONCLUDED that Mr. Perkins was not to blame for the robbery.”

Other forms of the word: CONCLUSION, n.

CONCLUSIVE, adj.

DROUGHT.deftext:
a dry period

A DROUGHT is a long period of dry weather.

“All the grass turned brown and the crops failed during the DROUGHT.”

“The DROUGHT finally ended when a thunderstorm soaked the region.”

DROUGHT is sometimes used to mean any kind of long shortage or lack of something.

“The team finally ended its season-long scoring DROUGHT by getting four goals in a game.”

The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is flood, which is an opposite of DROUGHT.

EDIBLE.deftext:
fit to be eaten, suitable for food, not poisonous

Something that is EDIBLE is able to be eaten. (See -able under Suffixes.) The word does not mean that something tastes good or is good for you to eat, only that it is fit to be eaten.

“The food was so bad it was barely EDIBLE.”

“This fruit will not be EDIBLE until it ripens.”

The plural noun EDIBLES is a fancy word for food. EDIBLES are things which are fit to be eaten.

Other forms of the word: EDIBLES, n.

PRIVILEGE.deftext:
priv’-lij) n.: a special right, special benefit

A PRIVILEGE is a special right which is given to some but not to others.

“He was given the PRIVILEGE of watching television until eleven o’clock on weekends.”

“We have the PRIVILEGE of parking our car on this street.”

“Should doctors have special PRIVILEGES the rest of us don’t have?”

Sworn duty is often chosen as the meaning of PRIVILEGE. This phrase is actually just about an opposite of PRIVILEGE. A duty is something you have to do; a PRIVILEGE is something you are allowed to do.

Other forms of the word: PRIVILEGED, adj.

questions.prompt: Can you PEER at something that is far away?
Is eating cake a TASK for most people?
Is it safe to be in front of an AVALANCHE?
If you are on the THRESHOLD of something, have you just completed it?
Does a caterpillar undergo a TRANSFORMATION when it becomes a butterfly?
Do people usually expect a REPLY when they ask a question?
Should a person who can't speak Spanish become a TUTOR of it?
If a clock is ten minutes fast, does it give you the ACCURATE time?
Do most adults need ASSISTANCE in putting on their clothes?
Does dinner usually CONCLUDE with dessert?
When food turns rotten, does it become EDIBLE?
Do some people have more PRIVILEGES than others?
The old man PEERED at Jim for several minutes before recognizing him.
He nodded his head to SIGNIFY that he was ready.
Sandra had the difficult TASK of getting the house ready for the party.
The announcement of the job opening produced an AVALANCHE of applications for it.
George couldn't make up his mind to go in; he just stood on the THRESHOLD and looked around.
His company TRANSFORMED him from the Chicago office to the New York office.
He REPLIED to her greeting with a nod.
When you are failing a course, it might be wise to get a TUTOR.
The cement factory uses a rock-crushing machine to PULVERIZE stones.
Jim practiced for hours to increase his ACCURACY in shooting the basketball.
She ASSISTED that we all come to the party.
He CONCLUDED to them that he was going away.
The severe DROUGHT left two feet of snow on the ground.
As punishment, he was given the PRIVILEGE of taking out the garbage for a month.

SEIZE.deftext:
to grab, take, grasp, snatch

SEIZE means “to take suddenly and by force,” to grab or snatch.

“The child SEIZED the piece of candy and ran off with it.”

SEIZE is often used about grabbing a chance or opportunity.

“I will SEIZE every chance I get to practice skating.”

The noun from SEIZE is SEIZURE.

“He said that the police’s SEIZURE of his car was illegal.”

Find is the most commonly chosen wrong answer in the Pretest. Finding something is not the same as SEIZING it, however.

Other forms of the word: SEIZURE, n.

GAINFUL.deftext:
producing a gain, profitable

A GAIN is an increase or a profit.

“The stock market made a GAIN of five points yester- day.”

Something which is GAINFUL produces a GAIN. (See -ful under Suffixes.) GAINFUL is used about jobs, businesses, and similar activities which earn money for the person doing them.

“After years of doing only volunteer work, she decided to seek GAINFJJL employment.”

“He was good at what he did, but it wasn’t a very GAINFUL trade.”

Other forms of the word: GAIN, n., v.

INDUSTRIOUS.deftext:
hardworking, diligent, busy

One meaning of the word INDUSTRY is “steady attention to business,” hard work.

“His success was due to years of steady INDUSTRY.”

INDUSTRIOUS means “full of INDUSTRY,” hardworking, and is used about people. See -ous under Suffixes.

“He was a very INDUSTRIOUS student; he always seemed to be doing his homework.”

“You will have to be more INDUSTRIOUS in doing your job if you want to get a raise.”

The most commonly chosen wrong answer is brilliant. This is perhaps due to a confusion between INDUSTRIOUS and illustrious. Illustrious means famous, distinguished.

“You should be INDUSTRIOUS if you ever hope to become illustrious.”

Other forms of the word: INDUSTRY, n.

MANIAC.deftext:
a madman, lunatic

MANIA is a violent form of insanity or madness. A MAN- IAC is a raving madman.

“That MANIAC is chopping down all the trees in the parks.”

Often MANIA is used in a weaker sense to mean “extreme enthusiasm,” a craze.

“There was a sudden MANIA for collecting match- book covers.”

MANIAC is also sometimes used in this weaker sense.

“He was a MANIAC for playing pinball. You couldn’t drag him away from the machine.

” Other forms of the word: MANIA, n.

OMIT.deftext:
to leave out, leave undone

To OMIT something is to leave it out, to fail to include it or do it.

“She OMITTED my name from the list.”

“I OMITTED doing my homework last night.”

“Please OMIT the first two pages and start with the third.”

An OMISSION is an act of leaving out.

“We were all upset by the OMISSION of his name from the list.”

Other forms of the word: OMISSION, n.

MYSTIFY.deftext:
to puzzle, make mysterious, confuse, baffle

MYSTIFY is the verb form of MYSTERY. See -fy under Suffixes. To MYSTIFY means to make mysterious; if you are MYSTIFIED, you are completely puzzled.

“Does the difference between a prefix and a suffix MYSTIFY you?”

“The magician MYSTIFIES us with his tricks.”

“The police were MYSTIFIED by the unusual case. They didn’t know how to go about solving it.”

Other forms of the word: MYSTERIOUS, adj.

MYSTERY, n.

MYSTIFICATION, n.

ORIGINAL.deftext:
first, earliest, new

The ORIGIN of something is its starting point, its beginning.

“What is the ORIGIN of the custom of giving gifts at Christmas?"

ORIGINAL means “having to do with a beginning.” See -al under Suffixes. Sometimes ORIGINAL gives the idea of first or earliest.

“She had the ORIGINAL idea, then everyone else copied her.”

Sometimes the word gives the idea of new or fresh.

“There were many ORIGINAL costumes at the party. No one had ever seen anything like them before.”

Other forms of the word: ORIGIN, n.

ORIGINALITY, n.

ORIGINATE, v.

PREY.deftext:
a victim

Animals which are or can be killed and eaten by other animals are called PREY.

“The worm is the usual PREY of the robin.

” People can also be PREY when they are the victim of a criminal, a disease, or the like.

“The pickpocket carefully chose his PREY in the crowd.

” To “fall PREY to” something is to become a victim of it. “Everyone in the family fell PREY to the illness.

” PREY is also used as a verb.

“The wolf PREYS upon the herds of sheep.”

REBOUND.deftext:
rE-bownd’) v.: to bounce back, spring back

See re- under Prefixes. To bound is to bounce or leap. To REBOUND is to bounce back, like a ball when it is thrown against something.

“The golf ball REBOUNDED from the tree and hit him on the head.

” REBOUND is also used about someone or something that “bounces back” from a disappointment or setback.

“The movie industry is starting to REBOUND after several years of losing money.”

“Stan REBOUNDED from his illness to become more active than ever.

SCAMPER.deftext:
to run quickly, scurry, move hastily

SCAMPER means “to run quickly or playfully,” to scurry about.

“The children SCAMPERED about the lawn as they played tag.”

“The mice SCAMPERED toward the hole when I turned on the light.”

The most commonly chosen wrong answer is jump up. SCAMPER is used just about running, not jumping.

SNARL.deftext:
to growl, bare the teeth, speak harshly

SNARL means to growl or bare one’s teeth like a dog. SNARLING indicates anger or hostility.

“The dog SNARLED at the cat to keep her away from the food.”

“The watchdog SNARLED in warning, so we went no further.”

When people SNARL, they don’t usually bare their teeth, but they do speak with a growling sound, to express their anger or irritation.

“The man SNARLED at the children in his usual un- pleasant manner.”

SNARL is also a noun.

“The bad-tempered lady replied to his suggestion with a SNARL.”

OBSTACLE.deftext:
a barrier, hindrance, obstruction

An OBSTACLE is something that stands in the way of something else, something which stops progress or makes it difficult.

“They kept putting OBSTACLES in my way as I tried to walk up to the front of the room.”

An OBSTACLE does not have to be a physical object.

“Our game with Jefferson High is the only OBSTACLE left between us and the championship.”

“There are many OBSTACLES facing a person who tries to solve the problem of hunger in the world.”

SWAY.deftext:
to swing, move to and fro; to influence

SWAY means “to swing back and forth” the way trees do when the wind blows them.

“The flowers were SWAYING in the gentle breeze.”

“She was probably dizzy, because she SWAYED when she stood up.”

SWAY also has the meaning of control or influence. If you can SWAY something, then you can control its movement.

“The reporter tried to SWAY public opinion by writing misleading articles about the candidate.”

“Sam was SWAYED by their appeals, and finally agreed to help them.”

WITHER.deftext:
to dry up, waste away

When something WITHERS it dries up, it becomes stale and lifeless. |n“Without water, the plants WITHERED.”

“His hope of success WITHERED as he grew older.

” To WITHER something is to make it dry up or become lifeless.

“Old age WITHERED her once great beauty.”

WITHERING is an adjective which means “able to devastate, destroy, or stun.”

“The WITHERING fire from the machine guns halted the soldiers’ advance.

” A “WITHERING glance” is a look which is intended to stun a person or make him unable to act.

“Susan’s WITHERING glance stopped Bob in his tracks.”

Other forms of the word: WITHERING, adj.

IGNITE.deftext:
to set on fire, cause to burn; to catch fire, begin to burn

To IGNITE something is to set fire to it.

“The burning cigarette IGNITED the straw.”

“He IGNITED the blaze with just one match.

” When something IGNITES, it begins to burn.

“When we threw on a few matches, the fire IGNITED.”

IGNITE is also used in a broader sense to mean to excite, inflame.

“Carol’s speech IGNITED the crowd’s enthusiasm.”

I am MYSTIFIED by your unusual behavior.
This was. the most ORIGINAL idea for a party that I've heard in a long time.

Lack of a college degree was a major OBSTACLE between Cynthia and success.
Jack's opinions were SWAYED by everything he read or heard.
The long illness had WITHERED him: he was only fifty years old but he looked eighty.
We managed to IGNITE the fire by pouring water on it.

COMMOTION.deftext:
a disturbance; confusion, noise, excitement

A COMMOTION is a disturbance. You can see the word motion in COMMOTION. COMMOTION usually suggests a great deal of movement and, often, noise and excitement.

“I don’t know how you could sleep through all that COMMOTION.”

“The sudden appearance of the long-lost son during the reading of the will caused quite a COMMOTION.”

“The rubbish collectors made an awful COMMOTION as they banged the barrels around.”

“Despite the COMMOTION we were still able to carry on a conversation.”

AIL.deftext:
to trouble, be the matter with; to have some- thing the matter, be ill

When something AILS a person it troubles him, it causes him pain or discomfort. The word is used when we don’t know exactly what the matter is.

“He went to the doctor to find out what was AILING him.”

“Nothing AILED her that a long vacation couldn’t cure.”

When a person is AILING, something is the matter with him.

“She was always AILING. Ever day she had some kind of ache or pain.”

An AILMENT is an illness or a disorder.

“Bob had several AILMENTS, but none of them was serious enough for him to go into the hospital.”

Other forms of the word: AILMENT, n.

BATTER.deftext:
to beat, hit repeatedly/n BATTER means “to hit over and over again,” to beat. If a thing is BATTERED, it is usually beaten out of shape. If a person is BATTERED, he is usually deeply bruised or injured.

“During the storm, heavy waves BATTERED the houses on the shore and many were destroyed.”

“We used a heavy piece of wood to BATTER down the door.”

“The fighter was badly BATTERED during the boxing match.”

COMMAND.deftext:
an order

A COMMAND is an order.

“The leader gave the COMMAND to begin marching.”

“He put his COMMANDS in writing so there would be no question about what they were supposed to do.”

“They refused to obey the foolish COMMAND to step over the edge of the cliff.

” COMMAND is also a verb.

“She COMMANDED them to leave the house or she would call the police.”

“The king COMMANDED the council to meet and approve his decisions.” Request is the most popular wrong answer in the Pretest. When you make a request you ask a person to do something. When you give a COMMAND you order him to do something.

DANGLE.deftext:
to swing, hang loosely

When something DANGLES it hangs loosely, so that it can swing back and forth.

“The wind chimes on the tree limb DANGLED in the breeze.”

“The baby tried to grab his mother’s necklace which was DANGLING in front of him.”

To DANGLE something is to swing it loosely. “He DANGLED the watch in front of our eyes.”

You can also DANGLE things like promises or jobs.

“Visions of great wealth were DANGLED before him in order to interest him in investing in their project.”

“The manager DANGLED the prospect of a better job for her within six months or so.”

DECEIVE.deftext:
to trick, mislead

To DECEIVE someone is to make him believe something that is false.

“Ellen DECEIVED me by making me think she really liked me.”

“Jane was DECEIVED into believing that the money would be used to feed the poor.”

“Don’t DECEIVE yourself. You can’t really climb that mountain.”

DECEIT is trickery, the quality or act of DECEIVNG.

“She accused Don of DECEIT in hiding the truth from her.”

“There was an element of DECEIT in the way the commercial presented the facts.”

Other forms of the word: DECEIT, n.

DECEITFUL, adj.

ASTOUND.deftext:
to amaze, overcome with surprise

To ASTOUND means to amaze, to astonish. Someone who is ASTOUNDED is much more than surprised; he is so astonished that he can barely think.

“The news of his victory ASTOUNDED all of us.” “She was ASTOUNDED to discover that one of her ancestors had been a duchess.”

“He was ASTOUNDED when he found out he had won the lottery.”

Other forms: ASTOUNDING, adj.

DISPUTE.deftext:
an argument, quarrel, verbal conflict /nA DISPUTE is an argument or quarrel.

“There was a long DISPUTE among them about who was the best.”

“Several minor DISPUTES between the countries finally led to full-scale war.”

“There can be no DISPUTE about it. We have to leave now.”

DISPUTE is also a verb. It can mean to argue.

“He DISPUTED with the other boys over how much to spend.”

Or it can mean “to call into question,” to argue against.

“The players all DISPUTED the referee’s call.”

“Jim DISPUTED everything his brother had said.”

EAVESDROP.deftext:
to listen secretly to a private conversation

An eave is the part of the roof which overhangs the side of a building. The eavesdrop is the water which falls from an eave, or the ground under the eave on which the water falls. To EAVESDROP originally meant to stand on this eavesdrop in order to listen to a conversation inside the building. From this the word has come to mean any kind of attempt to listen secretly to what people are saying in private. The word emphasizes sneakiness and secrecy. To EAVESDROP on someone else’s conversation is not a polite thing to do. An EAVESDROPPER is a person who listens secretly to conversation he is not supposed to hear.

“She stood outside the kitchen door to EAVESDROP on her parents’ conversation.”

Other forms of the word: EAVESDROPPER, n.

EMBLEM.deftext:
a symbol, sign, image

An EMBLEM is a picture, design, or figure that stands for something else. It could represent an idea, a school, a company, or the like.

“Our school’s EMBLEM is a screaming eagle.”

“The dove is an EMBLEM of peace. Many people pick motto as the meaning of EMBLEM. A motto is a short phrase that is associated with a country or a group of people; an EMBLEM doesn’t use words.

“Our motto is ‘Ever to excel.’ Our EMBLEM is a tiger cat ready to jump."

Other forms of the word: EMBLEMATIC, adj.

CLOAK.deftext:
a cape

A CLOAK is a long cape or sleeveless robe.

“She likes to wear her red CLOAK with the fur trim.”

“He held the dog under his CLOAK to keep it warm.”

CLOAK is also a verb meaning to cover or hide.

“He CLOAKED his hatred under a mask of smiles.”

“The house was CLOAKED in darkness; we couldn’t see it until we were almost there.”

“The mountain top is always CLOAKED in mist.”

Dress is the most commonly chosen incorrect answer. Both a dress and a CLOAK are articles of clothing, but they are not the same thing.

ESTIMATE.deftext:
to judge, rate, evaluate

To ESTIMATE is to make a judgment about something without having complete information.

“The teacher ESTIMATED that half of her students would pass the test.”

“We tried to ESTIMATE how long it would take us to finish the job.”

“No one could ESTIMATE the height of the mountain.”

An ESTIMATE is this kind of a judgment. As a noun, the word is pronounced es’-t:rmit.

“He didn’t know exactly how many people were coming to the party. He had to make an ESTIMATE.”

Other forms of the word: ESTIMATION, n.

FRAGMENT.deftext:
a part, piece A FRAGMENT is a separate or incomplete part of something, especially a part that is broken off. “We recovered several FRAGMENTS of the broken glass, but some are still missing.”

“He could only remember FRAGMENTS of the song; he had forgotten most of it.”

“They overheard FRAGMENTS of the conversation going on in the next room.“nFRAGMENTARY is an adjective which means “made up of FRAGMENTS,” incomplete.

“We have received only FRAGMENTARY reports of what happened there.”

Other forms of the word: FRAGMENTARY, adj.

HYMN.deftext:
a song of praise, usually to God

A HYMN is a song praising God. It is usually sung in a church service of some kind.

“They sang his favorite HYMN in church that Sunday.”

HYMN is also sometimes used for any song of praise.

“He wrote a solemn HYMN in honor of his nation’s independence.”

DONATION.deftext:
a gift, present, contribution

A DONATION is a gift or contribution, usually given to a charity of some kind.

“Every year we give a DONATION to the Heart Fund.” “After the disaster, the people whose homes had been destroyed needed DONATIONS of food and clothing.”

“He asked everyone for a small DONATION to buy a going-away present for George.”

When you make a DONATION, you DONATE.

“She refused to DONATE anything to the party.”

“We will accept whatever you choose to DONATE.”

Other forms of the word: DONATE, v.

STAMPEDE.deftext: a wild rush, sudden charge A STAMPEDE is a sudden, wild rush, usually of animals that have become frightened and run blindly. In a STAM- PEDE the animals are out of control; they are so crazy with fear they will trample anything in their way. “The cattle STAMPEDE destroyed the field of new corn.” “Don’t shoot your rifle now. The noise will cause a STAMPEDE.” STAMPEDE can also be used in a general sense about any wild rush. “The announcement of the big sale almost caused a STAMPEDE of shoppers to the store.” STAMPEDE is also a verb, which means to rush wildly or overrun. “The starving people STAMPEDED the supply wagons.

PROCLAIM.deftext: to declare openly, announce To PROCLAIM something is to announce it openly and publicly. “After he won the fight the boxer was PROCLAIMED champion of the world.” “When his father died the noblemen PROCLAIMED him king.” Often PROCLAIM has an official sense to it. “The governor PROCLAIMED next Monday a state holiday.” A PROCLAMATION is an official announcement. “Lincoln issued a PROCLAMATION that ended slavery in America.” Other forms of the word: PROCLAMATION, n.

INCIDENT.deftext: in’-sÔøΩdant) n.: an event, occurrence, happening An INCIDENT is simply something that happens, an event. Usually an INCIDENT is small or unimportant. “It was just one of those unpleasant INCIDENTS that happen every day.” Often, though, the word is used about a seemingly minor event which could lead to serious consequences. “The arrest of the novelist became a serious interna- tional INCIDENT.” “There were so many violent INCIDENTS at the bor- der that both countries threatened to declare war.”

MINDFUL.deftext: aware, careful, attentive MINDFUL is made up of two parts: mind and ful. See -ful under Suffixes. If your mind is full of something, you are very aware of it. MINDFUL means “keeping in mind,” aware. “He was MINDFUL of the orders he had been given.” “You should be MINDFUL of the danger.” “You must be MINDFUL that some of these animals could hurt you.” Usage: MINDFUL is usually followed by of.

PREVIOUS.deftext: former, earlier, prior PREVIOUS means “happening before” something else, former. See pre- under Prefixes. “All the PREVIOUS reports were wrong. Only the one we are putting out now is correct.” “We did well that season, but we did even better in the PREVIOUS season.” “After working there for a while he went back to his PREVIOUS job as a salesman.” PREVIOUS is often used with to to mean before. “PREVIOUS to the speech there was a wonderful din- ner.”

QUARANTINE.deftext: to isolate or separate from others to prevent the spread of a disease QUARANTINE is both a verb and a noun. To QUARANTINE a person is to keep him apart from others while he has a disease, or while he is suspected of having a disease, to make sure that the disease doesn’t spread. QUARAN- TINE comes from the Latin word for forty, because originally a person had to be kept isolated for a period of forty days. “You can take your dog to England, but it will have to be kept in QUARANTINE for six months.” “The entire ship was QUARANTINED when one of the passengers came down with smallpox.”

RECREATION.deftext: play, amusement RECREATION is something that refreshes you by pro- viding you with amusement or entertainment. “Walking is a pleasant RECREATION.” “His favorite RECREATION is watching television.” “She works too hard. She hardly has any time for RECREATION.” The adjective from RECREATION is RECREATIONAL. RECREATIONAL activities are things like games, sports, or hobbies which provide RECREATION. Other forms of the word: RECREATIONAL, adj.

SEGMENT.deftext: a part, section, division A SEGMENT is a section, a piece of a larger whole. “One SEGMENT of the magazine is made up of business reports.” “Mr. Sweeney is the counselor for a large SEGMENT of the junior class.” “Mrs. Ames gave each of the children a SEGMENT of the orange.”

SUBMERGE.deftext: to place underwater; to go under water, sink - See sub- under Prefixes. To SUBMERGE something is to plunge it into water. “The blacksmith quickly SUBMERGED the glowing horseshoe in a bucket of water.” When something SUBMERGES, it goes underwater. “The submarine SUBMERGED and quickly disappeared from sight.” “The treasure lay SUBMERGED in ten feet of water.”

TURQUOISE.deftext: ter’-koyz) adj.: blue- green TURQUOISE, when used as a noun, is a stone that is often blue-green in color. TURQUOISE, as an adjective, is used about anything with this blue-green color. “Her eyes are almost TURQUOISE in color.” “My TURQUOISE dress is the color of sea at mid- day.”

UTMOST.deftext: greatest, most extreme UTMOST means “of the highest degree possible"-that is, the furthest, the most, the greatest, and so on. “This job requires the UTMOST skill and intelli- gence.” “This meeting will take place in the UTMOST secrecy.” UTMOST is also a noun, meaning “the most that is possible or that one can do.” “He enjoyed life to the UTMOST"-that is, to the greatest degree possible. “This hotel will give you the UTMOST in comfort and service.” “We will do our UTMOST to finish the job on Saturday.”

VICTOR.deftext: a winner, conqueror A VICTOR is a person who defeats another in battle or any other kind of contest. “This year the VICTOR in the weight-lifting contest was a Russian.” “Harry Smith will be our mayor next year because he was the VICTOR in last week’s election.” A VICTOR wins a VICTORY; he is VICTORIOUS. “After his famous VICTORY, the VICTORIOUS general received all the glory due a VICTOR.” Other forms of the word: VICTORY, n. VICTORIOUS, adj.

DWELL.deftext: to live, reside; to speak, write, or think at length To DWELL in or at a place is to make your home there. “She DWELT all her life in the house where she was born.” “Many interesting people DWELL in that section of town.” In another sense, to DWELL on or upon something is to speak, write, or think about it at length. “I hate to DWELL on this, but you still owe me five dollars.” “In the first few chapters the author DWELLS on the problems of the early settlers.” Other forms of the word: DWELLING, n. Usage: The past tense of DWELL is DWELT or DWELLED.

QUESTIONABLE.deftext: doubtful, uncertain See -able under Suffixes. Something which is QUES- TIONABLE is able to be QUESTIONED, is open to QUESTION. “The referee made a QUESTIONABLE call"-that is, we are not certain that it was wrong, but we don’t think it was right. “It was QUESTIONABLE whether or not we would make it to school on time.” “He thought our results were QUESTIONABLE, so we checked them and discovered we had made a mistake.” Certain is the most commonly chosen incorrect answer on the Pretest. It is the exact opposite of QUESTIONABLE. Perhaps people who choose certain are confusing QUES- TIONABLE with unquestionable, which means “not open to QUESTION,” certain. Other forms of the word: QUESTION, n., v.

ROUSE.deftext: to awaken, stir, excite To ROUSE someone is to stir or awaken him. “The fire alarm ROUSED them from their sleep.” You can ROUSE someone to something as well as from something. “The speaker’s words ROUSED the crowd to action.” “I was ROUSED to anger by his insults.” ROUSE is often used with up. “They ROUSED up their friends and made them help too.” ROUSING is an adjective which means exciting or stir- ring. “We gave a ROUSING cheer when the team came on the field.” Other forms of the word: ROUSING, adj.

WAIL.deftext:
to cry, weep

To WAIL is to cry, usually long and loud in a voice that expresses deep unhappiness or pain; to make a loud, high-pitched sound.

“The baby WAILED when we took her bottle away.”

“We could hear the siren WAIL in the distance.”

WAIL is also a noun.

“Jane gave out a loud WAIL when she saw that every- one had left without her.”

ABSURD.deftext:
gb-zerd’) adj.: ridiculous, foolish, unreasonable

Something that is ABSURD makes no sense; it is not reasonable.

“It was freezing outside when he made the ABSURD suggestion that we all go swimming.”

“You may think the plan is reasonable, but I consider it ABSURD.”

“The television show was completely ABSURD. I’ve never seen a sillier program.”

The noun from ABSURD is ABSURDITY, which means ridiculousness or foolishness. “She understands the ABSURDITY of pretending to be richer than she is.”

Other forms of the word: ABSURDITY, n.

DEVOUR.deftext:
to eat, eat up, consume

To DEVOUR something is to eat it up greedily.

“He was so hungry that he DEVOURED the entire pizza at once.”

DEVOUR can also mean “to use up as if by eating greedily.”

“The raging fire DEVOURED an entire city block.”

“He liked her writing so much that he DEVOURED each book in one sitting"-that is, he read each one quickly and eagerly.

CEASE.deftext:
to stop, halt, end

To CEASE is to stop, to bring or come to an end.

“The teacher told them to CEASE talking.”

“When the rain CEASED the children came out to play again.”

“Their club CEASED to exist many years ago.”

Other forms of the word: CEASELESS, adj.

ELIGIBLE.deftext:
fit to be chosen, desirable; qualified

See -able under Suffixes. ELIGIBLE comes from the same Latin word as elect; both words have to do with choosing. To elect is to choose, particularly to choose someone for public office. An ELIGIBLE person is fit or qualified to be chosen. Sometimes this means the person has satisfied legal or other requirements: if you are “EL- IGIBLE for football,” it means, usually, that your school grades are high enough for you to be allowed to play on a team.

“Previous winners are not ELIGIBLE to enter the con- test again.”

Sometimes ELIGIBLE simply means “fit to be chosen” because the person or thing is good or desirable: “EL- IGIBLE bachelors” are single men who are suitable or desirable for marriage.

Other forms of the word: ELIGIBILITY, n.

AMATEUR.deftext:
am’-ÔøΩter or am’-g- tyUr) adj.: nonprofessional

AMATEUR means not professional, that is, “not paid for what is being done.” AMATEUR comes from a Latin word meaning to love, and is used about people who do something for the love of it, or as a pastime, not to earn money.

“He was an AMATEUR tennis player; he never played the game for money.”

“We enjoyed the AMATEUR production of Romeo and Juliet.”

AMATEUR can also be used as a noun and means “a person who does something for the love of it or as a pastime.”

“Many AMATEURS eventually become professionals.”

AMATEUR often, but not always, suggests that the person is inexperienced and not very good at what he is doing.

“He’s just an AMATEUR at this. He’s only been doing it for a couple of months.”

“She has become such a great pianist that we can no longer call her an AMATEUR.”

EXCLUDE.deftext:
to keep out, bar, leave out

See ex- under Prefixes. EXCLUDE means to shut out, to keep someone or something from getting in. You can EX- CLUDE either persons or things.

“Everyone agreed we had to EXCLUDE him from the club.”

“They decided their report would EXCLUDE all mention of the incident.”

“We can EXCLUDE the possibility that you committed the crime, since you were out of the country at the time.”

The adjective from EXCLUDE is EXCLUSIVE. EXCLUSIVE stores deal only with certain rich customers. An EXCLUSIVE in a newspaper is a piece of news which only that newspaper has uncovered, and which it prints before anyone else.

Other forms of the word: EXCLUSION, n.

EXCLUSIVE, adj., n.

HOIST.deftext:
to raise, lift

HOIST means to lift. The word is especially used about lifting something very heavy by mechanical means.

“They HOISTED the boat out of the water with ropes and pulleys.”

“The movers had difficulty HOISTING the piano up to the third floor.”

HOIST can also be used as a noun and means “a device for lifting.”

“They used the HOIST to lift the engine out of the car.”

The most commonly chosen wrong answer on the Pretest is steal. This is probably due to a confusion of HOIST with heist, which means a robbery.

IMPERSONATE.deftext:
to pretend to be, act the part of

To IMPERSONATE someone is to pretend you are that person, to act his part.

“The robber got into the apartment by IMPERSONATING a telephone repairman.”

“She IMPERSONATED the movie star so well it was hard to believe she was only a waitress.”

The noun from IMPERSONATE is IMPERSONATION.

“His clever IMPERSONATION fooled everyone.”

Many people think that to IMPERSONATE someone is to make fun of him. But you can pretend to be a person without making fun of him.

Other forms of the word: IMPERSONATION, n.

EXPOSE.deftext:
to uncover, leave open; to disclose, make known

To EXPOSE is to put out in the open what has previously been protected, hidden, or secret. EXPOSE can be used about physical objects and people.

“The statue was EXPOSED to the wind and the rain.”

“The destruction of the fort EXPOSED the soldiers to enemy gunfire.”

EXPOSE can also be used about plots and secrets.

“The reporter EXPOSED the secret plot to overthrow the government.”

EXPOSURE is a noun form of EXPOSE. To die of EXPOSURE means to die from being outside in the cold or the heat for too long.

“The EXPOSURE of his crimes shocked everyone.”

“Too much EXPOSURE to X rays is dangerous.”

” Other forms of the word: EXPOSURE, n.

KERNEL.deftext:
a seed, core, central part

A KERNEL is the soft inner part of a nut or a fruit stone. It is also the whole grain or seed of a cereal like wheat or corn.

“The KERNELS of corn were cut from the ears and put into cans.”

In general use, KERNEL means “the central or most important part of something.”

“Although I disagree with much of what you say, there is a KERNEL of truth in it"-that is, an important, essential part of it is true.

LEASE.deftext:
to rent

A LEASE is a contract renting lands, buildings, or the like to someone for a certain period of time. To LEASE something is to rent it to or from someone.

“He LEASED the farm from its owner for ten years.”

“The man LEASED the automobile to us for six months.”

The most common mistake on the Pretest is sell. To LEASE something involves paying money for the use of it for a certain period of time. But it does not involve buying or selling.

PENITENTIARY.deftext:
a prison, reformatory

PENITENTIARY is related to the word penitent, which means sorry. A PENITENTIARY is a place where people are sent as punishment for crimes they have committed. In this country, a PENITENTIARY is always a state or federal prison for people who have committed serious crimes.n“He entered the PENITENTIARY to begin his five-year sentence for robbery.”

“He worked as a guard in the state’s largest PENITENTIARY.”

ACCELERATE.deftext:
to speed up, hasten, go faster

To ACCELERATE something is to make it go faster, to speed it up.

“Fertilizer ACCELERATES the growth of most plants.”

“The regular program takes six months; the ACCELERATED program takes only three months.”

When something ACCELERATES, it speeds up.

“The car ACCELERATED to sixty miles an hour very quickly.”

In a car, the ACCELERATOR, or gas pedal, controls the car’s speed.

“He pressed down on the ACCELERATOR in order to pass the car in front of him.”

Other forms of the word: ACCELERATION, n.

ACCELERATOR, n.

PRECISE.deftext:
exact, certain, correct

PRECISE means exact, “without error or unclearness.”

“He says he’ll come some time next week, but he can’t be more PRECISE than that.”

“Donna tried to be PRECISE in her description of the car.”

“The bank knew the PRECISE amount of money he had in his savings account.”

“The game will start at PRECISELY eight o’clock- not a minute sooner or later.”

Other forms of the word: PRECISION, n.

After listening to the same song for two hours, he was glad when it CEASED.
The chair is so ELIGIBLE it will fall apart when someone sits in it.
He enjoyed being an AMATEUR chess player and didn't care whether or not he made any money at it.
Walter was EXCLUDED from taking part because he was too young.

Sally can do a great IMPERSONATION of her aunt.
Our digging EXPOSED some ancient statues that had been buried for centuries.
There wasn't a KERNEL of truth to the rumor that the teacher was quitting.
Mr. Allen makes a good income by LEASING apartments he owns.
The judge sentenced him to ten years in the PENITENTIARY.
They told us we were going too fast and should ACCELERATE our pace instead.
The PRECISE value of the painting is from two to ten thousand dollars or so.

CONFLICT.deftext:
a struggle, battle, quarrel, clash

CONFLICT comes from a Latin word which means “a striking together.” See con- under Prefixes. A CONFLICT is a situation in which people, nations, events, or interests disagree or interfere with one another. It could be as major as a war or battle.

“During the CONFLICT ten thousand soldiers lost their lives.”

Or a CONFLICT could be minor. “She had a CONFLICT between Math and English. Both classes met at the same time.” CONFLICT is also a verb, meaning to clash or disagree. As a verb the word is pronounced k:in-flikt’. “Their stories of what happened CONFLICT, so who is telling the truth?”

“His latest statement CONFLICTS with several earlier statements he made.”

The most commonly chosen incorrect answer in the Pretest is injury. An injury may be the result of a CONFLICT, but the two words do not have the same meaning.

PROSPER.deftext:
to succeed, flourish

When someone PROSPERS he is succeeding or doing well. The word usually suggests continued and steadily increasing success. The word often suggests financial suc- cess.

“He PROSPERED in his new business.”

It can be used about other kinds of success as well.

“Our cat was sickly for a while, but with the proper medicine and a better diet he began to PROSPER.”

Things like companies or countries can also PROSPER.

“The town PROSPERED when the highway was built near it.”

Other forms of the word: PROSPERITY, n.

PROSPEROUS, adj.

REAP.deftext:
to harvest, gather

To REAP is to cut down and gather in a crop, especially a crop of grain.

“They worked all day to REAP the wheat.”

In a general sense, REAP means “to get or win as a result of your work.”

“He hoped to REAP the benefits of his college education.”

“The inventor REAPED a fortune from this machine.”

CAVITY.deftext:
a hole, empty space

CAVITY is related to the word cave. A CAVITY is a hole, a hollowed-out space in a solid object. A CAVITY in a tooth is a hole caused by decay.

“In a hidden CAVITY in the wall they found a sack of gold.”

“The dentist found several CAVITIES in the child’s teeth.” Many people pick tooth as the meaning of CAVITY on the Pretest. These people have heard the word used, but don’t know its exact meaning. A CAVITY is a hole in a tooth, not the tooth itself.

SHRIVEL.deftext:
to shrink, wither, dry up and wrinkle

To SHRIVEL is to shrink in size and become dry and wrinkled. Often something SHRIVELS because of heat.

“He threw the note into the fireplace where it SHRIV- ELED up as it burned.”

Or because of age or illness: “When people get very old, their skin SHRIVELS.”

“In the old book we found a SHRIVELED leaf which someone had wanted to keep.”

SHRIVEL can also be used about anything that can be said to dry up and shrink.

“His once great talent seemed to SHRIVEL with age.”

Usage: SHRIVEL is often followed by up.

SLAY.deftext:
to murder, kill

To SLAY someone is to put him to death by force, to murder him. SLAY is a literary word, more often used in print than in ordinary conversation.

“The bank guard was SLAIN by an unknown gun- man.”

“The giant SLEW him with one swing of his mighty fist.”

Usage: The past tense of SLAY is SLEW. The past participle is SLAIN.

THRASH.deftext:
to beat, pound, whip; to move violently

THRASH means to beat, usually repeatedly with a stick or whip.

“In the spring he always had to THRASH the carpets with a rug beater.”

“Mr. Jones took out his anger at the world by THRASHING his dog.”

Because the idea of waving the arms about in beating something is included in THRASH, the word has also come to mean simply “to move or toss about violently.”

“In her sleep Debbie THRASHED around so much that she kicked off all her covers.”

ACQUAINTANCE.deftext:
familiarity; a person one knows slightly

To be ACQUAINTED with something is to be familiar with it. The word suggests only a slight knowledge, not a deep understanding.

“He speaks two languages very well and is ACQUAINTED with a dozen more.” To be ACQUAINTED with a person is to know him, although usually not very well.

“I am ACQUAINTED with Bill. I have spoken to him a few times.” ACQUAINTANCE is a noun from ACQUAINT. See -ance under Suffixes. ACQUAINTANCE is a general familiarity with something, but not a thorough knowledge. “Ralph has some ACQUAINTANCE with legal matters, although he has never studied law.”

An ACQUAINTANCE is someone you know slightly, not quite a friend. Other forms of the word: ACQUAINT, v.

ACQUAINTED, adj.

Usage: ACQUAINTANCE, when it means familiarity, is usually followed by with.

BANQUET.deftext:
a feast, elaborate meal

A BANQUET is a large, elaborate meal attended by many people. It is usually given in honor of someone or to mark a special occasion.

“The championship football team was given a large BANQUET to celebrate their victory.” “Five hundred people were at the BANQUET to honor Mr. Jones on his retirement.”

“When he saw all the food and drink on the table he said this wasn’t just a regular meal, it was a BANQUET.”

REDUCE.deftext:
to make less, make smaller, lessen, shrink

To REDUCE something is to make it smaller or less.

“The driver REDUCED his speed as he went around the corner.”

“Alice REDUCED her weight by going without lunch.”

“We must REDUCE the amount of money we spend.”

“The soldier’s rank was REDUCED from sergeant to corporal.”

REDUCTION is the noun from REDUCE.

“There has been a great REDUCTION in the number of mistakes since we started checking the work more carefully.”

“I will wait for a REDUCTION in the price before I buy it.”

The most common mistake on the Pretest is to think that REDUCE means end. You do not end something by RE- DUCING it, you just make the size or amount of it smaller. Other forms of the word: REDUCTION, n.

BLOATED.deftext:
swollen, puffed up

When something is BLOATED it is swollen beyond its normal size, usually with a liquid or gas.

BLOATED usually gives the sense of being puffed up in an unhealthy way.

“After drinking so much water she felt BLOATED.”

“Her legs became BLOATED as a result of the dis- ease.”

Other forms of the word: BLOAT, v.

CLUTCH.deftext:
to seize, grab

To CLUTCH something is to seize it and hold on to it tightly, like a bird grasping something in its claws.

“He CLUTCHED the kitten so tightly that it tried to wriggle free.”

“The baby CLUTCHED its bottle with both hands.”

To CLUTCH at something is to try to get hold of it.

“Whenever she was frightened she would CLUTCH at her mother’s hand.”

CLUTCH is also a noun, meaning grasp or control. It is often used in the plural.

“The child was in the CLUTCHES of evil kidnappers.”

STAGGER.deftext:
to move unsteadily, totter, sway

STAGGER means to move unsteadily or to sway. Someone who is STAGGERING looks as if he is about to fall.

“The drunken man STAGGERED down the street.”

“The fighter was hit so hard by his opponent that he STAGGERED.”

When something STAGGERS you, it almost knocks you down. STAGGER can be used in this sense about news or ideas which astonish or shock.

“The news of her accident STAGGERED me.”

“Everyone was STAGGERED by the increase in the cost of living.”

Fall down is the most popular wrong answer. Someone who STAGGERS may be about to fall, but STAGGER does not mean to fall down.

COMMITMENT.deftext:
a pledge, obligation, promise

One meaning of the verb to COMMIT is to pledge or undertake.

“The governor has COMMITTED himself to lowering taxes this year.”

A COMMITMENT is something to which you are pledged, a promise. See -ment under Suffixes.

“She forgot all about her COMMITMENT to sing in the show.”

“You made a COMMITMENT to help me move this morning. You can’t back out now.”

COMMITMENT is also the state of being COMMIT- TED.

“His COMMITMENT to their cause lessened when they started talking about violence.”

Other forms of the word: COMMIT, v.

DEBRIS.deftext:
ruins, rubbish, refuse

Note the pronunciation. DEBRIS is a French word and keeps its French pronunciation. DEBRIS is the scattered broken pieces of something that has fallen apart or been destroyed.

“The ground was covered with DEBRIS after the train wreck.”

“It took weeks to clean up the DEBRIS left behind by the flood.”

“After the fire there was nothing but DEBRIS where the house had once stood.”

PROTEST.deftext:
to object to, talk against, disapprove of

PROTEST is a word that has undergone a complete change of meaning. PROTEST used to mean to speak for something. See pro- under Prefixes. This use is still found in the expression “to PROTEST your innocence"-that is, to declare or speak in favor of your innocence. Now, however, PROTEST usually means to speak against something.

“The loser PROTESTED the decision against him.”

“The college students PROTESTED against the war.”

“The workers PROTESTED that they weren’t paid enough.”

PROTEST is also a noun, pronounced prO’-test.

“They ignored our PROTESTS and cut down the tree anyway.”

ISOLATED.deftext:
alone, solitary, apart

ISOLATED comes from a Latin word meaning island. Someone or something that is ISOLATED is cut off, like an island, from other persons or things.

“We live on a very ISOLATED farm. There’s no one else for miles around.”

“The doctors said the patient should be kept ISOLATED so that he doesn’t give the disease to anyone else.”

To ISOLATE something is to put or keep it apart from others.

“We tried to ISOLATE the problems and solve them one by one.”

Other forms of the word: ISOLATE, v.

ISOLATION, n.

DEDICATED.deftext:
devoted, committed, zealous

To DEDICATE something is to devote it to a particular use, person, or goal.

“She DEDICATED the book to her parents.”

“He DEDICATED his life to finding a cure for the common cold.”

Someone who is DEDICATED is devoted to a cause or a purpose.

“She is a very DEDICATED musician. She practices many hours every day.”

“They are DEDICATED to proving their father’s innocence.”

“There aren’t enough DEDICATED men in the party. Too many of them just don’t seem to care."

Other forms of the word: DEDICATE, v.

DEDICATION, n.

FLAWLESS.deftext:
perfect, faultless

A FLAW is a faulty part of something, like a crack in a dish or an imperfection in a jewel. FLAWLESS means “having no FLAW.” See -less under Suffixes. “The diamond was FLAWLESS. I have never seen such a perfect stone.”

“His FLAWLESS reputation was spoiled by that one stupid act.”

“Donna memorized the poem and then recited it FLAWLESSLY to the class.”

Many people choose bad as the meaning of FLAWLESS. Bad is just about the opposite in meaning of FLAWLESS. People who choose it perhaps know what a FLAW is, but do not know what the suffix -less means.

Other forms of the word: FLAW, n.

FLAWLESSLY, adv.

DISRUPT.deftext:
to break up, throw into disorder

See dis- under Prefixes. The rupt part of the word means break. It is also found in words like interrupt and rupture. To DISRUPT something is to break it apart, to destroy the way it normally works. Very often the word suggests that this is only happening for a short time.

“The electrical storm DISRUPTED telephone service for several hours.”

“His angry speech DISRUPTED the conference.”

“Her attempt to teach the class was totally DISRUPTED by the noise outside.”

“The painters DISRUPTED our office completely. We didn’t know where to find anything, where to sit, or what to do."

Other forms of the word: DISRUPTION, n.

DISRUPTIVE, adj.

FULFILL.deftext:
to carry out, complete, satisfy, accomplish

To FULFILL originally meant what it sounds like: to fill up, make full. It is no longer used in this way. Today it means to do something fully, to complete or accomplish it.

“Jane FULFILLED her promise to complete the job on time.”

“Alan has FULFILLED all the requirements for be- coming a lifeguard.”

“This product FULFILLED all our expectations. It is just what we wanted.”

HORDE.deftext:
a crowd, mob, throng, swarm

A HORDE was originally a wandering tribe of Mongols (an Asian people). Today HORDE is used about any large number of people or things, especially when they are rough or savage.

“HORDES of fans pushed against the gates of the stadium screaming to be let in.”

“A HORDE of children tramped through the house, leaving their dirty fingerprints on everything.”

INTERNAL.deftext:
inner, interior

INTERNAL means “having to do with the inside” of something, inner. See in-, under Prefixes. INTERNAL injuries are injuries suffered inside the body. “The president claimed the foreign government was interfering in the INTERNAL affairs of his country.”

“They carefully removed the cover to get at the INTERNAL parts of the machine.”

The opposite of INTERNAL is external, which means outside, outer. See ex under Prefixes.

JUNCTION.deftext:
a joining, meeting-place, union, connection

A JUNCTION is a joining, a coming together of two or more things. A JUNCTION is also a place where the joining occurs.

“They built a town at the JUNCTION of the two railroad lines"-that is, where the two lines met and crossed. The most popular wrong answer on the Pretest is dividing, which is an opposite of JUNCTION.

NUISANCE.deftext:
a bother, annoyance

A NUISANCE is a person or thing that causes trouble or worry to others.

“This table is in everyone’s way. It’s nothing but a NUISANCE.”

“That boy is making a NUISANCE of himself, teasing his sister while she’s trying to do her homework.”

“The hole in the sidewalk wasn’t really dangerous, but it was a NUISANCE for us to have to walk around it all the time.”

Complaint is the most popular wrong answer. A NUISANCE is likely to cause people to complain, but is not the complaint itself.

LOYAL.deftext:
faithful, true, devoted

To be LOYAL is to be devoted or faithful to a person, cause, or ideal.

“The brave soldier was LOYAL to his country and would not reveal military secrets even under torture.”

“The LOYAL dog jumped into the river to save its drowning master.”

LOYALTY, the noun form of the word, is the quality of being faithful.

“We admired the child’s constant LOYALTY to her aged father.”

Other forms of the word: LOYALTY, n.

POSSESS.deftext:
to have, own

To POSSESS something is to have it.

“She POSSESSES great wealth.”

“He POSSESSES a lot of charm.”

“This coin POSSESSES little value.”

POSSESSION is the owning or having of something.

“He came into POSSESSION of the painting.”

POSSESSIONS are things which someone has.

“All her POSSESSIONS were destroyed in the fire.”

Other forms of the word: POSSESSION, n.

POSSESSIVE, adj.

DISTRESS.deftext:
to trouble, upset, disturb, bother

To DISTRESS someone is to cause him pain or sorrow.

“It DISTRESSES me to see you so unhappy.”

“She was DISTRESSED by the news of her husband’s disappearance.”

“We have received DISTRESSING news about an air- plane crash.”

DISTRESS is also a noun, meaning suffering or misfortune. “The ship radioed that it was in DISTRESS and was in danger of sinking."

“He tried to relieve Susan’s DISTRESS by telling her that everything would turn out all right in the end.”

Other forms of the word: DISTRESSING, adj.

PRECIOUS.deftext:
valuable, costly, priceless, dear

PRECIOUS is related to the word price. Something that is PRECIOUS has a high price, is of great value.

“These PRECIOUS jewels are worth a fortune to us.”

PRECIOUS is also used about things which are of such value that they have no price.

“My children are PRECIOUS to me. I wouldn’t do anything to harm them.”

“We have a few PRECIOUS hours in which to find the bomb before it goes off.”

Many people choose rare as the right answer. Often something is PRECIOUS because it is rare, but the two words do not have the same meaning.

PURSUE.deftext:
to chase, follow, go after

To PURSUE something is to follow after it. You can PURSUE anything: a car, a person, success, happiness, and so on.

“The police PVRSUED the escaped prisoner.”

“He was PURSUED by shouts as he left the meeting.”

“All people should have the right to PURSUE happiness.”

PURSUIT is the noun from PURSUE.

“Everyone joined in the PURSUIT of the criminal.”

Other forms of the word: PURSUIT, n.

questions.prompt: Do people usually PROTEST when they win a prize?
When a mother kisses her baby, is she ISOLATING it?
Would a DEDICATED teacher be likely to spend extra time helping her students?
Would an artist like to paint a FLAWLESS picture?
Would the noise of a jackhammer DISRUPT a concert?
If you keep a promise, have you FULFILLED it?
Would a HORDE usually be peaceful and friendly?
Is your hair an INTERNAL part of you?
Could your wrist be called the JUNCTION between your hand and your arm?
Would a boss want to hire workers who would be LOYAL to the company?
Can a person POSSESS a sense of humor?
Is it DISTRESSING to win a race?
Do you always catch something that you PURSUE?
They PROTESTED that there wasn't enough time to do what he wanted them to do.
Hermits are people who avoid the company of others and would rather be ISOLATED.
The mayor DEDICATED the new city hall to the people of the city.
Jack made only a couple of mistakes in his FLAWLESS performance.
The volcano looked like it was going to DISRUPT at any minute.
He FULFILLED the cup to overflowing.
The sudden arrival of HORDES of insects ruined the barbecue.
Bob opened up the machine to get at its INTERNAL parts.
This set of railroad tracks had many JUNCTIONS with other sets of tracks.
The dog became such a NUISANCE that finally we had to give it away.
Benedict Arnold showed his LOYALTY to the United States by giving secrets to the British.
He POSSESSED a magic ring that could make him invisible.
The teacher DISTRESSED to them the importance of studying hard.
His weekends are PRECIOUS to him. He won't let anyone disturb them.
He didn't care whom he hurt in his PURSUIT of great wealth.

TORMENT.deftext:
great pain, agony, suffering

TORMENT is great pain and suffering.

“We could tell that our cat was in TORMENT because every few minutes he would give a great cry of pain."

Mental suffering can also be TORMENT.

“The missing boy’s parents were in TORMENT.”

TORMENT is also a verb which means “to cause great pain to,” to torture. As a verb the word is pronounced torment’ or torment.

“He was TORMENTED by a severe headache.”

Sometimes it simply means to annoy.

“He constantly teases and TORMENTS his sister.”

SLACKEN.deftext:
to slow down; to make looser

SLACKEN means to slow down.

“The runner SLACKENED his pace when his leg began to hurt.”

“We enjoyed being on the beach once the wind SLACKENED.” SLACKEN is also used to mean “to make looser.”

“The horse was easier to control after Bill learned to SLACKEN the reins."

The adjective form of SLACKEN is SLACK, which means “not busy, or not tense or taut.”

“It was a SLACK season for his business; few customers came to his shop.”

“The rope was SLACK; it hung loosely from the sail.”

SLACK is also a noun.

“There was some SLACK in the rope.”

Other forms of the word: SLACK, adj., n.

QUALIFIED.deftext:
suited, fit, competent; limited, restricted

To QUALIFY a person is to make him fit for something like a job or an award.

“Your score on the test QUALIFIES you for a prize.”

Someone who is QUALIFIED, therefore, is fit or competent for something.

“Both of them were well QUALIFIED for the job.”

“Only QUALIFIED experts should work with bombs.”

“He wasn’t QUALIFIED to run in the race because he didn’t enter on time.”

Another meaning of QUALIFIED is limited, restricted. To give your “QUALIFIED approval” to something is to approve it with some limitations, not wholeheartedly.

Other forms of the word: QUALIFICATION, n.

QUALIFY, v.

RESTRAIN.deftext:
to hold back, curb, limit, restrict

To RESTRAIN someone is to hold him back from doing something. See re- under Prefixes.

“We held on to Bill to RESTRAIN him from hitting the other boy.”

“It was difficult for him to RESTRAIN his temper. He got angry very easily.”

“She could not RESTRAIN a smile at the child’s question.”

RESTRAINT is the noun from RESTRAIN. A RESTRAINT is something that holds you back.

“The prisoner hated the RESTRAINTS that had been placed on his freedom.”

RESTRAINT is also the act of holding back.

“We must exercise RESTRAINT in eating the cookies” -that is, we must hold back our desire to eat too many of them.

Other forms of the word: RESTRAINT, n.

SLUMBER.deftext:
sleep SLUMBER means sleep, usually peaceful sleep.

SLUMBER can be used as either a noun or a verb.

“The baby is quietly SLUMBERING in his crib.”

“As soon as the medicine took effect, he fell into a deep SLUMBER.”

“He lay in peaceful SLUMBER, unaware of the noise.”

CONSUME.deftext:
to use up; to eat; to destroy

CONSUME means to use up, so that there is nothing left.

“By the end of the winter all the firewood we had cut was CONSUMED.”

“Her pay is CONSUMED by the necessary things like food and rent, so there’s nothing left over for fun.”

CONSUME also means to eat or drink; in other words, to use up food.

“We CONSUMED the meal in complete silence.”

“The guests at the party CONSUMED two cases of soft drinks.”

In a slightly different sense, CONSUME can mean to destroy. “Our house and all our belongings were CONSUMED in the fire.”

Other forms of the word: CONSUMER, n.

SUMMON.deftext:
to send for, call together, call forth

To SUMMON someone is to send for him, to ask or require him to come. The word usually suggests that the re- quest is urgent, or that the person doing the SUMMONING is powerful and not to be disobeyed.

“The king SUMMONED all the noblemen to his castle.”

“The ringing of the bell SUMMONED them to their next class.”

To SUMMON up something is to call it forth.

“She tried to SUMMON up a smile, but she was just too unhappy.”

In law, a SUMMONS is a notice ordering a person to appear in court.

“When the witness didn’t appear in court, the judge is- sued a SUMMONS requiring him to come.”

Other forms of the word: SUMMONS, n.

TOLERATE.deftext:
to bear, stand, put up with, endure

TOLERATE means to bea or put up with. The word suggests that you don’t like something, but you endure it because you have to, or because it’s not bad enough to make you resist it.

“Harry doesn’t like children, but he TOLERATES them when he’s visiting friends who have children.”

“She couldn’t TOLERATE having the puppy jump up on her.”

People who TOLERATE things are called TOLERANT.

“He’s very TOLERANT of little mistakes, but she yells about everything.”

Other forms of the word: TOLERANCE, n.

TOLERANT, adj.

UNSETTLE.deftext:
to disturb, make troubled, make uncertain

One meaning of the verb SETTLE is to calm.

“This medicine will SETTLE your stomach if you are not feeling well.”

UNSETTLE is the opposite of SETTLE used in this sense. See un- under Prefixes. To UNSETTLE is to make someone or something disturbed or disordered.

“Monica’s attitude of superiority UNSETTLED Julia.”

“The UNSETTLED conditions at the end of the war eventually calmed down during the years of peace that followed.”

“Her final remark was very UNSETTLING. He worried about it all the way home.”

VOW.deftext:
a promise, oath

A VOW is a solemn promise or oath, often taken in some kind of ceremony.

“He made a solemn VOW to find the person who had killed her.”

“She took a VOW of secrecy when she joined the club.” VOW is also a verb meaning to promise or swear. “We VOW to be true to one another forever.”

“Scarlett VOWED that she would never go hungry again.”

CRISIS.deftext:
an emergency, climax, turning point

CRISIS comes from a Greek word meaning decision. A CRISIS is a point at which what happens in the future, good or bad, is decided. In medicine, for example, a CRI- SIS is the turning point in a serious disease, when the patient either starts to get better or dies.

“There was a political CRISIS in that country. No one knew who the next ruler would be."

“She was in the middle of a personal CRISIS then. Her husband was deciding whether he wanted a divorce.”

“That was quite a CRISIS. I’m glad things worked out all right.”

EPISODE.deftext:
an incident, scene, occurrence, one of a series of events

An EPISODE is a scene, incident, or story which is com- plete and interesting in itself, but which is also part of a larger story or series of events.

“The play had some exciting EPISODES, but in general was not very good.”

“It was not a very pleasant EPISODE in his career.”

Single programs in a television series are called EPISODES because they are complete by themselves, but are also part of the entire series.

Other forms of the word: EPISODIC, adj.

WEARY.deftext:
tired, worn out

WEARY means just about the same as tired, although it is a little stronger and suggests someone who has lost most of his energy or his interest.

“After the fifty mile march the soldiers were WEARY and ready for bed.”

“We were all WEARY by the time we had finished cleaning the house.”

WEARY is often followed by of.

“I am getting very WEARY of people always yelling at me.”

WEARY is also a verb, meaning to tire or become tired.

“They began to WEARY of the noise and confusion of city life.”

Unhappy is often chosen as the meaning of WEARY in the Pretest. Someone can be both physically WEARY and happy, though.

“The team was WEARY after the long game, but happy because they had won.”

Other forms of the word: WEARINESS, n.

WOE.deftext:
sorrow, trouble, grief

WOE is deep sorrow or misery.

“The field was a scene of WOE after the battle.”

In a related sense, a WOE is also a cause of sorrow or suffering, a trouble or misfortune.

“His WOES began when he fell and broke his leg.”

“She complained for hours about all the WOES of her life.”

The adjective form of WOE is WOEFUL. WOEFUL can mean unhappy.

“Jane had a WOEFUL look on her face when she heard the bad news.”

WOEFUL can also mean “of very poor quality,” wretched.

“This house is in WOEFUL condition. It needs a lot of work.”

Other forms of the word: WOEFUL, adj.

COMPLIMENT.deftext:
praise

A COMPLIMENT is a polite expression of praise or approval. When you tell people that you admire them or ap- prove of what they’re doing, you are giving them a COMPLIMENT.

“She received several COMPLIMENTS from her friends about her new dress.”

COMPLIMENT is also a verb and means “to express approval of or to give praise to.” As a verb the word is pronounced kom’-pl;)-ment.

“The teacher COMPLIMENTED him for raising his grade in French.”

“She COMPLIMENTED the way we cleaned the house.

Other forms of the word COMPLIMENTARY, adj.

questions.prompt: Are people happy to be in TORMENT?
Would a runner's speed SLACKEN as he tried to win a race?
Is a high school student QUALIFIED to be president of the United States?
Should someone who wants to commit murder be RESTRAINED?
Do people usually SLUMBER at night?
Would a fat person usually CONSUME a lot of food?
Could a principal SUMMON a student to his office?
Do TOLERANT people get angry easily?
Would seeing a ghost UNSETTLE a person?
Is it possible to break a VOW?
Would people be worried during a CRISIS?
Could there be several EPISODES in a novel?
Would most people be WEARY after running ten miles?
Is a playful kitten full of WOE?
Do most people like to receive a COMPLIMENT?
Pat was TORMENTED by the thought that he would soon have to take the test.
She SLACKENED them for not trying hard enough.
We felt that she was QUALIFIED for the job as an interpreter because she spoke French perfectly.
Gail disliked any RESTRAINTS on her activity. She wanted to do as she pleased.
The car SLUMBERED to a stop by the side of the road.
The climb up the mountain CONSUMED all our energy.
Cindy SUMMONED up all her remaining strength for the last mile of the race.
I simply cannot TOLERATE cigarette smoke.
She was UNSETTLED by the news that she might lose her job.
They received a beautiful blue VOW for a wedding present.
He survived one CRISIS after another during his career.
He called the Civil War one of the saddest EPISODES in American history.
Carla quickly began to WEARY of her dull job at the factory.
Her WOEFUL look told us that she was deeply unhappy.
Dick didn't think she meant it when she COMPLIMENTED him. He felt she was just praising him to make him feel better.

STRIVE.deftext:
to attempt, contend, struggle

To STRIVE is to put out great effort or energy in working or competing. The word suggests that what you are trying to do is difficult and that there are obstacles in the way of success.

“We must all STRIVE to do the best job we can.”

“They STROVE against impossible odds to reach the trapped miners.”

“The two of them STROVE to see who would win the prize.”

“You should STRIVE to understand the other person’s point of view.”

Usage: The past tense of STRIVE is STROVE.

IMPULSE.deftext:
an urge, sudden desire

The basic meaning of IMPULSE is a push or thrust. When used about people, it refers to an urge or feeling which pushes someone to act in a certain way.

“He is always helping people. He has an IMPULSE to do good.”

The word usually suggests that this urge or feeling is sudden and not thought out.

“He decided on an IMPULSE to take a trip to Hawaii.”

“He acts on IMPULSE and regrets it later.”

Someone who is always acting on IMPULSE is IMPULSIVE.

“She is an IMPULSIVE shopper. If something looks good to her, she buys it right away.”

ssOther forms of the word: IMPULSIVE, adj.

DETECT.deftext:
to discover, find, find out

To DETECT something is to discover it, to find out that it exists or is present.

“You can’t DETECT these germs unless you look through a microscope."

“She DETECTED the odor of leaking gas in the basement.”

“Didn’t you DETECT something wrong in the way he was walking?”

A DETECTIVE is someone whose job is to uncover facts about a person or an event. DETECTION is the act of DETECTING.

“Early DETECTION of the disease enables doctors to cure it completely.”

Other forms of the word: DETECTION, n. DETECTIVE, n.

DISREGARD.deftext:
to ignore, neglect

To regard something is to notice it, to pay attention to it. To DISREGARD something is to pay no attention or give no thought to it. See dis- under Prefixes.

“He DISREGARDED his own safety in order to save the others.”

“She DISREGARDED the ‘No Trespassing’ sign and went into the building anyway.”

“We DISREGARDED the other team’s insults.”

DISREGARD is also a noun, meaning “lack of attention,” neglect.

“The rude stranger showed a complete DISREGARD for the rights of others.”

HARNESS.deftext:
hahr’-nis) v.: to put to work, use, control

A HARNESS is the equipment which is put on a horse to attach him to a wagon or plow so that he can pull it. Thus, to HARNESS something is to get control of it so that you can put it to work for you. “Will we be able to HARNESS the energy of the sun?”

“He was a good writer, but he could never quite HARNESS his wild imagination.”

“They HARNESSED the power of the waterfall to produce cheap electricity.”

DISSECT.deftext:
to cut apart, examine, analyze

See dis- under Prefixes. The sec part of DISSECT comes from a Latin word meaning tocut. It is also found in words like intersect and section. DISSECT means to cut apart, especially the parts of an animal or plant in order to study them.

“In biology class we had to DISSECT a frog in order to learn about the workings of the body.”

In a broader sense, DISSECT can mean “to examine and analyze in detail,” the way a scientist would in DISSECTING an animal.

“The critic DISSECTED the author’s theory and showed just how silly it was.”

Other forms of the word: DISSECTION, n.

INFURIATE.deftext:
to anger, enrage, madden

See in- under Prefixes, and -ate under Suffixes. FURY is violent anger, rage. To INFURIATE someone is to fill him with FURY.

“The coach’s decision to cut Bill from the team INFU- RIATED him.”

“I am INFURIATED by people who don’t know what they are doing.”

MOBILE.deftext:
able to move or change easily

MOBILE means “able to move quickly or easily.”

A MOBILE home is a house which can be moved from place to place.

“They put wheels on the table so that it would be more MOBILE.”

“Their repair crews were very MOBILE. They could go to any part of the country on a moment’s notice.”

The noun from MOBILE is MOBILITY.

“She has lost all her MOBILITY since she broke her ankle.”

Other forms of the word: MOBILITY, n.

SOOTHE.deftext:
to calm, quiet, comfort, relieve

SOOTHE means “to give relief or comfort to,” to calm or quiet. You can SOOTHE a sorrow or a physical pain.

“She SOOTHED the sick child with a lullaby.”

“Cough drops help to SOOTHE a sore throat.”

“He found that listening to music helped to SOOTHE his mind.”

“He SOOTHED the nervous horse by speaking quietly and calmly.”

Other forms of the word: SOOTHING, adj.

MOURN.deftext:
to feel sorrow, grieve

To MOURN is to feel a deep sorrow, often over a person’s death.

“Everyone MOURNED when they heard he had died.”

“The team MOURNED the loss of its captain.”

You can MOURN other things besides death.

“He MOURNED the passing of so many nice old customs.”

MOURNING is the act of someone who MOURNS. To be in MOURNING is to feel deep sorrow and to express it by wearing black clothing, for example, or by flying flags at half mast.

“The whole nation was in MOURNING when the President died."

The most commonly chosen wrong answer in the Pretest is complain. Complain is used about things that annoy you; MOURN would only be used about events that cause you great unhappiness.

Other forms of the word: MOURNING, n.

STABLE.deftext:
solid, firm, steady Something that is

STABLE is unlikely to move; it is so firmly fixed in place that it is hard to change. STABLE is used about things and qualities.

“His house was so STABLE and well built that it survived the earthquake.”

“The price of meat remained STABLE for some time.”

“She was a very STABLE person. You could count on her never to do anything foolish or unexpected.”

The verb form of STABLE is STABILIZE. To STABILIZE means to make or become steady.

“The government tried to STABILIZE prices.”

“They developed a new way of STABILIZING small boats.”

Other forms of the word: STABILIZE, v.

STABILITY, n.

SWINDLE.deftext:
to cheat, trick

To SWINDLE someone is to cheat or trick him in order to get money.

“The investors were SWINDLED out of thousands of dollars by the scheme.”

“Confidence men make their living by SWINDLING unsuspecting people.”

SWINDLE is also a noun which means “an act of cheating, trickery, or fraud.”

“He was involved in a SWINDLE which cheated many people out of their hard-earned money.”

ABUNDANT.deftext:
plentiful

ABUNDANT means “more than enough,” plentiful.

“We have an ABUNDANT supply of food in the cabin for the winter.”

“There is ABUNDANT rain in this area; it’s good farmland.”

The noun form, ABUNDANCE, means a great supply, plenty.

“The library has an ABUNDANCE of books.”

“There used to be an ABUNDANCE offish in this river; now there are none.”

Other forms of the word: ABUNDANCE, n.

STRIDE.deftext:
a long step

A STRIDE is a single long step. A STRIDE is also the distance covered in a long step.

“He crossed the room in several STRIDES.”

“They were only a few STRIDES away from the finish line.”

STRIDE is also a verb. To STRIDE is to take long steps, especially in an energetic manner.

“They STRIDE quickly through the dark streets.”

“Yesterday he STRODE up to the teacher and asked to speak with her.”

The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is leap, which is close to the meaning of STRIDE, but not the same.

Usage: The past tense of STRIDE is STRODE.

TRIBUTE.deftext:
an honor, gift; payment, taxation

A TRIBUTE is an honor or gift given to somebody to show respect or give thanks.

“With a charming speech, she accepted the TRIBUTE to her skill.”

“This statue is a TRIBUTE to the memory of soldiers who have fallen in war.”

TRIBUTE is often used in the phrase “to pay TRIBUTE,” which means to give honor.

“We gathered to pay TRIBUTE to the man who founded our company fifty years ago.”

TRIBUTE also means a kind of payment or taxation a conqueror gets from those he has conquered. “The king set the yearly TRIBUTE from the town at a hundred gold pieces.”

Usage: TRIBUTE, when it means honor or gift, is usually followed by to.
