INFANTILE.deftext:
childish, babyish

An INFANT is a baby, a child in the first year or so of life, before it begins to walk or talk. INFANTILE means “of or relating to INFANTS.” INFANTILE diseases are sicknesses common to INFANTS. When used about adults, INFANTILE usually has a bad sense, “lacking the maturity or reasoning power of an adult.”

“His INFANTILE behavior during the speech shocked everyone.”

“Her INFANTILE attitude about doing household chores was most unpleasant.”

Other forms of the word: INFANT, n.

FLABBERGAST.deftext:
to surprise, astonish, amaze, astound

To FLABBERGAST someone is to fill him with surprise and astonishment, to make him so surprised that he can barely speak.

“His odd behavior FLABBERGASTED us.”

Someone who is FLABBERGASTED is amazed, aston- ished.

“I was FLABBERGASTED to discover that I had won first prize.”

In the Pretest, many people choose delighted as the word closest in meaning to FLABBERGASTED. But you can be FLABBERGASTED and not be delighted at all.

“Sue was FLABBERGASTED when she learned that she had failed the exam. She thought she had done quite well.”

ACQUIRE.deftext:
to get, obtain

ACQUIRE means to get or obtain. You can ACQUIRE objects, or nonphysical things like knowledge or skill.

“After some hard bargaining, we ACQUIRED the house at a very low price.”

“She eventually ACQUIRED some skill in ice skating, but she was never really very good at it.”

“I’ve tried olives many times, but I haven’t been able to ACQUIRE a taste for them.”

LEISURE.deftext:
free time, spare time, ease

LEISURE is time which is free from work, spare time.

“The first settlers in this country had little LEISURE. Almost all their time was spent trying to survive in the wilderness.”

“In this country sports are a popular LEISURE activity.”

The phrase “at LEISURE” means “when one has free time” or “at one’s convenience.”

“Would you do me a favor and read through my report at your LEISURE?”

“While she was unemployed she was able to paint her entire house at LEISURE.”

Other forms of the word: LEISURELY, adj.

ETERNAL.deftext:
endless, lasting forever, timeless

Something is ETERNAL which lasts forever, which will never end.

“They promised ETERNAL love to one another.”

“Death finally brought him ETERNAL rest.”

ETERNAL is often used, in a joking way, to describe things that seem endless.

“This ETERNAL arguing has to stop!” The noun form of ETERNAL is ETERNITY, which means endless time.

“We hope it will never change for all ETERNITY.”

ETERNITY is also used for time that seems ETERNAL.

“We had to wait an ETERNITY for the bus to come.”

Other forms of the word: ETERNITY, n.

ADEOUATE.deftext:
sufficient, enough

ADEQUATE means “equal to what is needed,” sufficient. “She does not get ADEQUATE pay for the amount of work she does.”

“I think you will find that there is an ADEQUATE supply of food in the freezer.”

Often ADEQUATE has the sense of just barely enough.

“The supply of food is ADEQUATE for us, I suppose, but I wish we had more in case guests arrive.”

“He did an ADEQUATE job, although not an outstanding one.”

Other forms of the word: ADEQUACY, n.

DEJECTED.deftext:
downcast, unhappy

DEJECTED means unhappy or downcast. The word usually suggests being in low spirits for a short time because of some disappointment or sad event.

“You seem DEJECTED today. I haven’t seen you smile once.”

“She was DEJECTED because the picnic had been called off.”

“We’ve tried to cheer him up, but he’s still DEJECTED.”

“Getting a D on a test would make anyone feel DEJECTED.”

EXCLAIM.deftext:
to cry out suddenly and loudly

To EXCLAIM is to cry out or speak loudly because you are surprised, angry, hurt, happy, or feel some other strong emotion.

“He EXCLAIMED angrily at the amount of time it was taking.”

“They EXCLAIMED in delight over the idea of going to the beach.”

“We EXCLAIMED with wonder at the size of the elephant.“nAn EXCLAMATION is the act of EXCLAIMING, or something that has been EXCLAIMED.

“He stopped suddenly with an EXCLAMATION of surprise.

An EXCLAMATION point(!) is a sign that a sentence is very forceful and, if spoken, would be EXCLAIMED.

“‘We will never give in!’ they EXCLAIMED.”

Other forms of the word: EXCLAMATION, n.

GENUINE.deftext:
real, true, authentic, not faked

Something which is GENUINE is really what it is sup- posed to be. It isn’t fake or counterfeit.

“The man at the jewelry store said they were GENU- INE pearls.”

“I don’t think his sorrow is GENUINE. He just wants us to think he’s unhappy.”

“No one could be holier than she was. She was a GEN- UINE saint.”

GIBBERISH.deftext:
gib’-ÔøΩrish) n.: nonsense; confused, meaningless speech

GIBBERISH is confused speech or writing that is impossible to understand or make sense of.

“The child spoke nothing but GIBBERISH until she was seven years old.”

“He was trying to speak Chinese, but it sounded like GIBBERISH to me.”

GIBBERISH is often used about writing which is very technical or needlessly difficult to understand.

“His explanation of how the machine worked was so complicated that it seemed like GIBBERISH to us.”

HURL.deftext:
to throw forcefully, cast, fling

To HURL something is to throw it, especially with force or violence.

“They HURLED rocks down at us from the top of the castle.”

“The force of the explosion HURLED him to the ground.”

“At the sound of the trumpet they HURLED themselves at the enemy.”

In the Pretest, spin is often chosen as the meaning of HURL, perhaps because HURL sounds like twirl, and to spin something is to twirl it.

INVINCIBLE.deftext:
unconquerable, unbeatable See in- under Prefixes and -able under Suffixes. The vine part of the word comes from a Latin word meaning to conquer. Someone or something that is INVINCIBLE is not able to be beaten or conquered.

“We thought our team was INVINCIBLE until it finally lost a game.”

“His INVINCIBLE spirit overcame all obstacles.”

“The fort was INVINCIBLE: it withstood dozens of attacks.”

Other forms of the word: INVINCIBILITY, n.

JUSTICE.deftext:
fairness

JUSTICE is fairness, the quality of being fair or just, of giving to someone what he deserves.

“His sense of JUSTICE kept him from taking advantage of their problems.”

“We don’t want any favors, we only want JUSTICE.”

“He went into the courtroom expecting JUSTICE to be done, but the judge’s decision seemed quite unfair to him.”

Punishment and mercy are often chosen as synonyms for JUSTICE. Both have to do with JUSTICE, but they aren’t the same thing. JUSTICE often involves punishing someone, but not always. And a person who has too much mercy or kindness will not provide JUSTICE.

Other forms of the word: JUST, adj.

MELODIOUS.deftext:
full of melody, sweet sounding, tuneful

A MELODY is a tune, a pleasing succession of musical sounds. Something which is MELODIOUS has MELODY, sounds sweet and tuneful. See -ous under Suffixes.

“These songs are not very MELODIOUS. They are very unpleasant to hear.”

“She had a MELODIOUS voice. When she spoke, it sounded as if she were singing.”

Other forms of the word: MELODY, n.

GORGEOUS.deftext:
magnificent, colorful, superb, dazzling

Someone or something that is GORGEOUS looks wonderful, usually because it is so spectacular or colorful.

“We could see mile after mile of beautiful lakes and forests; the view was simply GORGEOUS.”

“She looked really GORGEOUS in her expensive new gown.”

Many people think GORGEOUS means pleasant, but GORGEOUS is much stronger than that. Something that is GORGEOUS is quite beautiful.

Do you ACQUIRE knowledge by reading?
Are the hours you spend in school your LEISURE time?
Is five dollars usually ADEQUATE money to buy a ten dollar book?

The teacher said she wouldn't put up with any more INFANTILE behavior in her class.
The teacher FLABBERGASTED them for talking in class.
She is going to get a new car, because she ACQUIRES it for her work as a traveling salesperson.
We sat on the porch drinking lemonade and enjoying our LEISURE.
It seemed an ETERNITY before we could see the doctor.
We had to get ADEQUATE food for the twenty people who were coming to the party.
Jim was DEJECTED when he heard that he couldn't go to the dance.
"Look! An island!" the shipwrecked sailor EXCLAIMED with relief.
Bob wasn't upset at all. His anger was completely GENUINE.
Pete sometimes sounds intelligent, but usually he speaks nothing but GIBBERISH.
The rocket HURLED up into the sky.
In his daydreams he became an INVINCIBLE crime fighter.
He said there's no JUSTICE in this world. The most evil people always seem to be the most successful.
She was very frightened and let out several MELODIOUS screams.
It was a GORGEOUS garden, full of very beautiful flowers.

INJURIOUS.deftext:
causing injury, harmful

INJURIOUS is the adjective from INJURY, which means harm, damage, wrongful action. INJURIOUS means “causing, or tending to cause, an INJURY.”

“Smoking is INJURIOUS to your health.”

“He complained about the INJURIOUS treatments he had received from the phony doctor.”

In the Pretest, wild is a common choice as the meaning of INJURIOUS, probably because of confusion with the word furious.

Other forms of the word: INJURE,v.INJURY,n.

MORSEL.deftext:
a bit, small piece, scrap

MORSEL comes from a Latin word meaning to bite. A MORSEL is a small piece of food that could be eaten in one bite.

“You must eat every MORSEL on your plate before you get dessert.”

“He ate the last MORSEL of bread, and then there was nothing left."

MORSEL can also be used about a small piece of news, knowledge, or the like.

“They picked up a few MORSELS of information about their ancestors there, but nothing very interesting.”

PILLAR.deftext:
a column, post

A PILLAR is a firm upright post which supports a ceiling or a building.

“Using all his strength Samson broke the PILLARS, and the building collapsed on top of him.”

PILLAR is also used generally about a person or thing that provides strong support.

“He was a PILLAR of the community. Without him this wouldn’t be as good a place to live.”

EXTERIOR.deftext:
outside, outer, external

See ex- under Prefixes. EXTERIOR means outer, outside.

“They painted the EXTERIOR walls of the house and left the inside walls alone.”

“The EXTERIOR appearance of the building had faded over the years from the wind and the rain.”

EXTERIOR can also be used as a noun. “He had a rugged EXTERIOR"—that is, his outside appearance was strong and rough looking. The opposite of EXTERIOR is interior, which means inner, inside.

PREPOSTEROUS.deftext:
absurd, completely foolish, totally unreasonable

Anything PREPOSTEROUS is absolutely absurd, completely without sense or reason. It comes from a Latin word meaning “having the back end in front.” See pre- under Prefixes and -ous under Suffixes.

“His ideas about the use of chewing gum to repair tires was PREPOSTEROUS.”

“She has the PREPOSTEROUS notion that telephone poles grow right where they are.”

“The book is PREPOSTEROUS. Nobody acts the way the author says they do.”

INSPIRE.deftext:
to influence, arouse, uplift, exalt, encourage

See in- under Prefixes. The spire part of the word comes from the Latin word for breathe, which is also the source for words like expire, perspire, and conspire. To INSPIRE people is to breathe life, purpose, excitement, or some other feeling into them, to uplift or encourage them.

“The coach’s speech at halftime INSPIRED the team to try even harder.”

“The teacher INSPIRED in Jane a desire to learn more about the subject.”

“We were all INSPIRED by your wonderful example.”

“The foreman’s harsh words INSPIRED a great deal of anger among the workers.”

Other forms of the word: INSPIRATION,n.

PROGRESS.deftext:
advance, forward movement PROGRESS is forward movement toward a goal. It is advancement or improvement. See pro- under Prefixes.

“We made some PROGRESS through the snowstorm, but finally we became stuck.”

“There was little PROGRESS in their efforts to end the war.”

“Scientists have made PROGRESS, but they still can- not cure the disease.”

The phrase “in PROGRESS” means “in the act of going forward,” still happening.

“He turned on the television show while it was in PROGRESS.”

PROGRESS is also a verb, pronounced pr:rgres’.

“He PROGRESSED rapidly for a while, but then seemed to get worse.”

Other forms of the word: PROGRESSION, n.

PROGRESSIVE, adj.

CONSULT.deftext:
to confer, seek the advice of, refer to

To CONSULT something is to go to it for information, to refer to it.n“He CONSULTED the dictionary for the correct spelling of the word.“n“Did you CONSULT the phone book before you dialed the number?“nYou can also CONSULT a person.

“The teacher CONSULTED the principal before taking her class to the museum.“nTo CONSULT with someone is to confer with him, to talk over a problem and get advice.

“She CONSULTED with three lawyers about the complicated case.”

“I want to CONSULT with another doctor before deciding about the operation.“nOther forms of the word: CONSULTANT, n.

CONSULTATION, n.

DAWDLE.deftext:
to waste time, delay

To DAWDLE is to spend too much time doing something.

“He would DAWDLE over his homework and never get it done.“n“If she liked what she was doing, she would rush right through it. If she didn’t, she would DAWDLE and waste time and finally leave it half finished.“n“Come straight home from school and don’t DAWDLE along the way!”

Talk stupidly is often picked as the synonym for DAWDLE. This is probably due to confusion with twaddle, which is a noun meaning “foolish, silly talk.”

SUPERVISE.deftext:
to oversee, superintend, direct

See super- under Prefixes. To SUPERVISE is to oversee work or workers, to look over them, so that you can make sure things are done right.

“I have to SUPERVISE every step of the job to make sure no mistakes are made.”

“The general himself SUPERVISED the landing of the soldiers.”

Someone who SUPERVISES is a SUPERVISOR. The act of SUPERVISING is SUPERVISION.

“He thought that SUPERVISION wasn’t really necessary. The workers could do the job by themselves.”

The most common mistake is to choose help as the meaning of SUPERVISE. To SUPERVISE people is to direct them, to give them orders, not to help them.

Other forms of the word: SUPERVISION, n.

SUPERVISOR, n.

SUPERVISORY, adj.

UNDERGO.deftext:
to experience, suffer

UNDERGO means to experience, usually to experience something unpleasant.

“We had to UNDERGO several tests before we were through.”

“My father will UNDERGO an operation for his heart murmur.”

“The witness UNDERWENT several hours of questioning at the trial yesterday.”

Usage: The past tense of UNDERGO is UNDERWENT.

DEPRESS.deftext:
to discourage, sadden; to lower, press down

See de- under Prefixes. To DEPRESS basically means to press down.

“When a car’s accelerator is DEPRESSED, the car goes faster.” DEPRESS is most often used in the sense “to press down on your spirits,” to discourage.

“The news of his death DEPRESSED all of us.”

“Joan was DEPRESSED by her failure to pass the course.”

“He has looked so DEPRESSED lately. Let’s try to cheer him up.”

Other forms of the word: DEPRESSING, adj. DEPRESSION, n.

HUMANE.deftext:
kind, compassionate, tender, benevolent

HUMANE, with an e, was once just another way of spelling human. The word has come to be used, however, only about the kindest or gentlest qualities of human beings. To be HUMANE is to be full of sympathy and consideration for other people or for animals.

“They were noted for their HUMANE treatment of the poor. No one was allowed to go hungry or home- less.”

“He was a HUMANE boss. He gave his workers time off if they really needed it.”

FEE.deftext:
a charge, payment

A FEE is a charge for services. It is usually for professional services, like those of a doctor or a lawyer.

“The lawyer’s FEE was so high that we wondered if it had been worthwhile going to court.”

The word can also be used about any charge made for a right or privilege.

“The club raised its membership FEE by five dollars.”

“There is a small FEE for the use of the tennis courts.”

INHABIT.deftext:
to live in, dwell in

See in-1 under Prefixes. To INHABIT a place is to live in it.

“Several million people INHABIT that city.”

“A family of raccoons INHABITS the woods behind our house.”

An INHABITANT is someone who INHABITS a place, a resident.

“The firemen rescued all the INHABITANTS of the building.

” Many people choose get used to as the meaning of IN- HABIT, probably because they are confused by the word habit.

Other forms of the word: INHABITANT, n.

The artist must have been INSPIRED when he painted that picture.
Bill's father kept him under close SUPERVISION while he used the chainsaw.

I tried to DEPRESS what I thought, hut no one would listen to me.
His study of the language had PROGRESSED to the point where he could read it easily.
I shall have to CONSULT with your father before I can make a decision.
He thought it was funny to frighten the boy by DAWDLING him over the side of the boat.
They were very HUMANE in caring for stray cats and dogs.
The doctor's FEE was much more than we expected.
We INHABIT a small shack at the edge of town.

CONTRACT.deftext:
an agreement

A CONTRACT is a legal agreement between two or more persons or companies to do something. For a CON- TRACT to be legal, both sides have to state that they will do something. For example, a person agrees to perform a service and a company agrees to pay him for it. If either side fails to live up to the agreement, it could be sued.

“She signed a CONTRACT with the company stating that she would do the job in six months for ten thou- sand dollars.”

“He said he didn’t have to do the work because it wasn’t in his CONTRACT with them.”

“Our CONTRACT expires at midnight. Unless we agree on a new one, no one will go to work.”

SLITHER.deftext:
to slide, slip

SLITHER is one of many words that begin with the letters sl and which have the meaning of slip or slide. The motion in SLITHER is like that of a snake sliding over the ground. To SLITHER is to slide along in a side-to-side way.

“The snake SLITHERED away into the bushes.”

“The children SLITHERED across the ice on their backsides.”

SLITHERY, the adjective form, means slippery.

“The wet soap was SLITHERY and hard to hold.”

Other forms of the word: SLITHERY, adj.

LEGISLATOR.deftext:
a lawmaker

LEGISLATOR comes from the Latin word for law, which is also the source of legal and legitimate. A LEGISLATOR is a person who makes laws, a member of a lawmaking body like the Senate or the House of Representatives.

“She was one of the three LEGISLATORS to oppose the president’s plan."

A LEGISLATURE is the body of persons who make laws. To LEGISLATE is to make laws. LEGISLATION is the act of making laws, or the laws made. On the Pretest, many people choose judge as the synonym for LEGISLATOR. But a judge belongs to a totally separate branch of government. Judges interpret the laws that LEGISLATORS make.

Other forms of the word: LEGISLATE, v.

LEGISLATION, n.

LEGISLATURE, n.

PARALLEL.deftext:
going in the same direction, side by side; similar

PARALLEL lines are lines which go in the same direction and, even if they went on forever, would never meet. So PARALLEL is used about things which run side by side without crossing each other.

“The two roads ran PARALLEL to each other for several miles before they branched off.”

In general use PARALLEL means “having the same course, nature, or tendency,” similar.n“There was a PARALLEL increase in both poverty and crime in that city.”

LOGICAL.deftext:
loj-ÔøΩkÔøΩI) adj.: agreeing with

LOGIC, reasonable LOGIC is sound reasoning.

“We all admired the LOGIC of her arguments.”

“There wasn’t much LOGIC in what he said.”

LOGICAL means “having LOGIC, according to LOGIC,” reasonable. See -al under Suffixes.

“His speech sounded impressive, but it wasn’t very LOGICAL. When you really studied it, it didn’t make any sense at all.”

“The LOGICAL place to start looking for the missing pen is wherever you saw it last.”

“She was a LOGICAL person. She never jumped to conclusions, and always had a good reason for what- ever she did.”

Other forms of the word: LOGIC, n.

FIENDISH.deftext:
devilish, cruel and wicked

A FIEND was originally an enemy, the opposite of a friend. From this it came to be used only about devils, who are the enemies of mankind. Now it is used generally about any very cruel or wicked person.

“He must have been a FIEND to murder them all in cold blood.”

Something which is FIENDISH is appropriate to a FIEND; it is cruel and savage. See -ish under Suffixes.

“He took a FIENDISH delight in pulling the wings off flies.”

“With a FIENDISH laugh he jumped out at them from behind the bush.”

“The FIENDISH old woman frightened little chil- dren.”

Other forms of the word: FIEND, n.

MONARCH.deftext:
a ruler, a king or queen

A MONARCH is someone, like a king or queen, who is the ruler of a kingdom or empire.

“Queen Victoria was the MONARCH of the British Empire for many years.”

“He dreamed of being a MONARCH and having power over millions of people.” A MONARCHY is a government ruled by a MONARCH. “England is a limited MONARCHY. Its king or queen has very little real power any more.” Other forms of the word: MONARCHY, n.

RECOLLECT.deftext:
to remember, recall, bring to mind again

To RECOLLECT is to remember, to call to mind. RECOLLECT usually suggests more effort than remember.

“He tried to RECOLLECT how he had fixed the television set before.”

“Do you RECOLLECT what their telephone number is?”

“I can’t quite RECOLLECT what the score of that game was.”

Other forms of the word: RECOLLECTION, n.

SNICKER.deftext:
to laugh, giggle

The word SNICKER is both a verb and a noun. SNICKER means to laugh or giggle, usually in an embarrassed or disrespectful fashion, as at a dirty joke.

“They SNICKERED at the cartoons in the magazine.”

“The speaker was annoyed at the SNICKERS from the back of the room.”

Usage: SNICKER is sometimes spelled snigger.

VERDICT.deftext:
a decision, judgment

n law, a VERDICT is a decision reached, by a jury for example, about the guilt or innocence of someone who is on trial.

“The jury returned a VERDICT of guilty on all the charges against him.”

“The jury’s VERDICT was that the defendant had to pay us the ten thousand dollars he owed us.”

VERDICT can also be used about any kind of decision or opinion, especially one reached after carefully weighing the evidence.

“The doctors’ VERDICT was that he only had six months to live.”

“The voters will return their VERDICT on the mayor’s performance in the election this fall.”

BARBARIC.deftext:
savage, uncivilized

A BARBARIAN is a person who is wild and almost completely uncivilized. It is said that the ancient Greeks coined the word because foreigners who didn’t speak Greek sounded as if they were saying nothing but barbar. BARBARIC and BARBAROUS are similar adjectives re- lated to BARBARIAN. BARBARIC means “of or like BARBARIANS,” wild, savage, uncivilized. See -ic under Suffixes.

“The way they treat prisoners in that jail is BARBARIC.”

“The wild, BARBARIC music drove the audience wild.”

BARBARIC is frequently confused with ancient. Ancient people were not all BARBARIC, however; and BARBARIC people still exist today.

Other forms of the word: BARBARIAN, n., adj.

BARBAROUS, adj.

DAMAGE.deftext:
harm, hurt, injury

DAMAGE is injury that causes some kind of loss, as in property, value, or usefulness.

“The storm caused a great deal of DAMAGE along the coast.”

“There was little DAMAGE to our car as a result of the accident.”

DAMAGE is also a verb, meaning to cause harm to.

“Those false rumors DAMAGED his reputation.”

“The early frost DAMAGED our crops.”

“His house was DAMAGED slightly when it was struck by lightning.”

FESTIVE.deftext:
joyous, merry

FESTIVE is related to the word feast, which is a large, splendid meal. Something which is FESTIVE is appropriate to a feast or a similar happy time.

“He wore his fancy shirt only on FESTIVE occasions"—that is, only at joyous times like Christmas, weddings, holidays, etc.

“Winning the championship put everyone in a FESTIVE mood; we celebrated all night.”

A FESTIVAL is an occasion for feasting or celebrating.

“The summer FESTIVAL was so much fun that we are going again next year.”

FESTIVITY is FESTIVE activity, merrymaking.

“The FESTIVITIES began with boat races and a singalong.”

Other forms of the word: FESTIVAL, n.

FESTIVITY, n.

SUSCEPTIBLE.deftext:
easily affected, easily influenced, sensitive

SUSCEPTIBLE means easily affected or influenced.

“Many people are SUSCEPTIBLE to the cold; they seem to sneeze and sniffle all winter long.”

“We feared that our defenses were SUSCEPTIBLE to an attack from the rear.”

The word is often used about people whose emotions or decisions are easily influenced.

“The king is SUSCEPTIBLE to flattery. If you flatter him, he’ll give you almost anything you want.”

“He is very stubborn; he is not even SUSCEPTIBLE to reason.”

Other forms of the word: SUSCEPTIBILITY, n.

Usage: SUSCEPTIBLE is usually followed by to.

DREAD.deftext:
to fear greatly, be terrified of

To DREAD something is to have a deep fear of it. DREAD is especially used about things that are going to happen in the future.

“I DREAD going to this party. I never have a good time at large parties.”

“Sally DREADED the math exam, but she ended up doing well on it."

DREAD is also a noun, meaning great fear.

“He has a DREAD of going into a dark house all by himself.”

“No one could cure her of her DREAD of spiders.”
